questions.text: A young male patient, aged 20, presents with increasing localized pain that developed gradually over time. Imaging via X-ray revealed sunray appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteosarcoma 

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor, accounting for approximately 20% of all cases. 
  • It most commonly occurs in the extremities. 
  • Approximately 75% of patients < 25 years of age; the average at diagnosis is 20 years are affected.
  • High-grade conventional intramedullary osteosarcoma is the most common subtype. 
  • It is a biologically complex and aggressive tumor involving a long bone's metaphysis, usually adjacent to a physis with the most significant growth, such as the proximal humerus, distal femur, or proximal tibia.
  • It has a slightly increased incidence in males than females. 
  • High-grade intramedullary osteosarcoma comprises approximately 80% of all osteosarcomas; 42% occur in the femur, 19% in the tibia, and 10% in the humerus. 
  • Symptoms of may be present for a significant amount of time, sometimes weeks to months, before patients seek evaluation. 
  • Most commonly, the presenting symptom is bone pain, particularly with activity. 
  • A history of traumatic musculoskeletal injury may or may not be reported. 
  • Pain and swelling at the local site, usually at the growing ends of an extremity or long bones, are the most common presenting symptoms. 
  • Physical examination findings include:
    • A palpable, tender mass
    • Decreased range of motion of adjacent joint, with possible effusion
    • Pain on weight-bearing or inability to bear weight
    • Local or regional lymphadenopathy (unusual)
    • Respiratory findings with metastatic forms
  • Radiographs of the conventional osteosarcoma usually demonstrates medullary and cortical bone destruction with mixed lytic and blastic appearance.
  • High-grade osteosarcoma is often described as having a permeative or moth-eaten appearance with a "sunburst" configuration due to aggressive periostitis or "codman triangle" configuration due to elevation of the periosteum away from the bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is an aggressive tumor of adolescents and young adults. It is the second most common primary bone malignancy in adolescents and young adults with a median age of 15 years. Patients often present with local symptoms such as pain, stiffness, or swelling for a few weeks or months. More than 50% of patients have intermittent pain that worsens at night. It is commonly found in the diaphysis of long bones but can occur in different locations with varying presentations. Bone or metastatic lesions within the long bone can present as pathological fractures. The pelvic location of Ewing sarcoma can present as back pain. The presence of systemic symptoms, including fever and weight loss, often indicates metastatic disease. Plain radiographs of the affected area may show destructive confluent '' moth-eaten" lesions, "Codman triangle" of the elevated periosteum, or multilayered "onion-skin" periosteal reaction.

 

 

Option B. Gout: Gout is among the most prevalent etiologies of chronic inflammatory arthritis, characterized by monosodium urate (MSU) monohydrate crystals deposition within tissues. It is characterized biochemically by extracellular fluid urate saturation, which is reflected by hyperuricemia in the blood, with plasma or serum urate concentrations exceeding 6.8 mg/dL. The etiology of is usually multifactorial, including genetic predisposition, medical comorbidities, and dietary factors. Older age and male sex are the common risk factors. The initial manifestation is an acute attack of arthritis, usually monoarticular, marked by the abrupt onset of severe pain and swelling. Maximum inflammation occurs within 12-24 hours. Gout flares are typically monoarticular, with 85-90% occurring in the lower extremities. The first metatarsophalangeal joint is the most commonly involved. The talar, subtalar, ankle, and knee can also be involved. On physical examination, the affected joint is red, swollen, warm, and tender. Tophi, subcutaneous deposits of urate which form nodules, can be found in patients with persistent hyperuricemia. Radiographically, joints show joint effusion (earliest sign), preservation of joint space until late stages of the disease, absence of periarticular osteopenia, eccentric erosions, and “punched-out” erosions with sclerotic margins in a marginal and juxta-articular distribution, with overhanging edges. The bone mineralization is normal. 

 

 

Option D. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcomas are malignant cartilaginous neoplasms that account for 20% of all primary malignant tumors of the bone. They usually arise in the pelvis or long bones. The majority of chondrosarcomas are sporadic, but they may develop from the malignant transformation of osteochondromas and enchondromas. Chondrosarcoma is a tumor of adulthood and older age. The majority of patients are older than 50 years of age, with a slight male predominance. The most common locations of involvement include the axial skeleton (pelvis, scapula, sternum, and ribs) followed by the proximal femur and proximal humerus. Involvement of the hands and feet is rare. Local swelling and pain are the most common presenting symptoms. The symptoms are usually of long duration (months to years). Plain radiography is used for initial evaluation as it allows the identification of the cartilaginous nature and the aggressiveness of the lesion. Plain x-rays may reveal lytic lesions in 50% cases, intralesional calcifications in 70% cases (popcorn calcification or rings and arcs calcification), endosteal scalloping, permeative or moth-eaten appearance in high-grade chondrosarcomas, and cortical remodeling, thickening, and periosteal reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer, and it often presents in adolescents and young adults (like this 20-year-old patient). 
  • A "sunray appearance" on X-ray is a classic sign of osteosarcoma, where bony spicules radiate outward from the tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.

 

Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:

  • Pioglitazone: A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • Aristolochic acid: Found in some herbal remedies.
  • Phenacetin: An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • Aminosalicylates: Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

questions.text: An 88-year-old male presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain. On physical examination, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115 bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72 mm of Hg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.

 

  • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding.
  • Most sensitive X-ray: CXR-PA erect.
  • Most sensitive Ix: CECT with oral contrast.
  • Next step: Resuscitation with IV fluids, Exploratory laparotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: Involves air in the pleural space, not under the diaphragm. The clinical presentation and X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: Typically presents with localized pain and fever, but X-ray findings would be more consistent with an abscess formation rather than free air.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While it might present with abdominal pain and distension, free air under the diaphragm is not a characteristic finding unless there is a concurrent bowel perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumoperitoneum is a critical finding indicating a potential perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, requiring immediate assessment and surgical intervention. This diagnosis is supported by the presence of free air under the diaphragm seen on the X-ray.

questions.text: The formula UV/P represents which one of the following renal functions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance in the kidneys. In this formula:

 

  • U stands for the Urinary concentration of the substance.
  • V stands for the Urinary volume or urinary flow rate.
  • P stands for the Plasma concentration of the substance.

 

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. The UV/P formula is applied to determine how effectively the kidneys are clearing a particular substance from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration Fraction: This is calculated as the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) divided by the Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This process involves the transfer of substances from the blood into the tubular fluid.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This process involves the movement of substances from the tubular fluid back into the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance by the kidneys, which reflects how efficiently the kidneys are filtering the blood.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department following a suspected stroke. Upon assessment, it is noted that the patient is able to speak fluently, but the words uttered lack coherent meaning and lacks understanding. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Wernicke's aphasia

 

Explanation:


Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent speech that lacks coherent meaning. Patients with this condition can speak in long sentences with normal grammar, but their speech may include unnecessary or made-up words, making it difficult for others to understand.

 

This condition results from a lesion in Wernicke's area, which is responsible for language comprehension. In this scenario, the patient's ability to speak fluently yet produce nonsensical speech indicates a disruption in language comprehension, hallmark features of Wernicke's aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conduction aphasia: This type of aphasia is caused by a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus, which connects Wernicke's and Broca's areas. Patients with conduction aphasia have good comprehension and fluent speech but struggle with repetition and may make phonemic errors.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is characterized by difficulty in finding the correct words, particularly nouns and verbs. Patients can understand speech and have fluent and grammatically correct speech but have trouble naming objects.

 

Option D. Broca's aphasia: This type of aphasia results from a lesion in Broca's area, leading to non-fluent, halting speech with good comprehension. Patients with Broca's aphasia have difficulty forming complete sentences and may produce short, broken phrases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's aphasia is identified by fluent but nonsensical speech due to impaired language comprehension.

questions.text: Definitive Investigation for a patient of dengue who presented with features of Dengue hemorrhagic syndrome since last 5 days is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RT-PCR

 

RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the most definitive investigation for diagnosing dengue, particularly in the first five days of illness. RT-PCR is highly sensitive and specific, capable of detecting the viral RNA present in the blood.

 

Although NS1 antigen detection is another option for early diagnosis, RT-PCR provides more reliable results, especially around the 3rd day of illness.

 

Studies indicate that within the first five days, RT-PCR is superior to the NS1 antigen test in detecting dengue infection. After five days, when the viral RNA levels decrease, ELISA IgM becomes a more suitable test as it detects the presence of antibodies developed against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS-1 antigen: The NS1 antigen test is useful in the early diagnosis of dengue, typically within the first few days of illness. However, it is most effective around the 2nd day of illness and is less reliable compared to RT-PCR by the 5th day.

 

Option C. Viral culture: Viral culture is not typically used in clinical settings for the diagnosis of dengue because it is time-consuming, requires specialized facilities, and is less practical for rapid diagnosis.

 

Option D. ELISA IgM: ELISA IgM is a serological test that detects antibodies produced in response to dengue infection. It becomes more effective after 5 days of illness, when the immune response is more developed, making it unsuitable for diagnosis within the first five days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms within the first five days, RT-PCR is the definitive diagnostic test due to its high sensitivity and ability to detect viral RNA during this critical period.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HPV 18

 

Explanation:

 

  • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection.
  • Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers.
  • Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35.
  • Genital warts, also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11). These types, referred to as low-risk, have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.

 

Genital warts are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact, although non-sexual transmission is also possible.

 

 

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are first-line medications prescribed for the treatment of genital warts.

 

IMIQUIMOD:

 

  • Imiquimod cream uses:
    • Actinic keratoses
    • Superficial basal cell carcinoma
    • Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
       
  • Mechanism of action: Activates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, leading to apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A HPV 2:

  • This type is considered low-risk and is commonly associated with common warts that affect the hands and feet, not with anogenital warts or cancer.

 

Option C & D HPV 6 and HPV 11:

  • These are both low-risk types that are associated with about 90% of genital warts but are not typically linked with cancer.
  • They are known to cause benign conditions like respiratory papillomatosis as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV 16 & 18 as high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers, and recognize that HPV 2, 6, and 11 are low-risk types not typically associated with cancer.
  • It’s crucial to know the distinction between low-risk and high-risk HPV types due to the differences in prognosis and management.
  • High-risk types warrant more aggressive monitoring and management due to their association with malignancy.

 

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43, 25.55

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 198

Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition 156, 157, 486

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 650

 

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: An adult patient presents with tall stature, pigeon chest deformity, long arm span, lens dislocation, and cardiac defects. This patient is likely to have a defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibrillin

 

The clinical presentation described is strongly suggests Marfan syndrome, a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue.

 

Marfan syndrome is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the formation of elastic fibers in connective tissue. Features of Marfan syndrome include tall stature, long arms, pigeon chest (pectus carinatum), lens dislocation (typically upward and temporal), and cardiac defects such as aortic aneurysm and mitral valve prolapse. The defect in fibrillin leads to the characteristic physical and systemic manifestations of the syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elastase: Elastase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of elastin and is associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, leading to conditions like emphysema. It is not related to Marfan syndrome.

 

Option C. Collagen: Collagen defects are associated with other connective tissue disorders, such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Alport syndrome. Collagen abnormalities do not explain the specific features of Marfan syndrome.

 

Option D. Laminin: Laminin is a major glycoprotein in the extracellular matrix, playing a key role in cell adhesion and structural integrity of tissues. It is not associated with Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan syndrome is characterized by a defect in fibrillin-1 due to mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to tall stature, skeletal deformities, lens dislocation, and cardiovascular abnormalities.

questions.text: A 65-year-old PLHIV patient came with cough, fever, and pneumonia. Biopsy shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV

 

In the biopsy image, the characteristic feature to note is the presence of inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and the cytoplasm of the cell, giving an appearance often described as "owl eye." This is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV can cause severe infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as patients living with HIV (PLHIV). The virus leads to the formation of large cells with nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause pneumonia, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not produce the distinctive "owl eye" inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. EBV: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is known for causing infectious mononucleosis and is associated with various lymphoproliferative disorders, but there is no inclusion bodies in the cells.

 

Option D. HSV2: Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2) can cause various infections, including pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, but it does not produce the specific "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of "owl eye" inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells in a biopsy is indicative of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those living with HIV.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not phosphorylated by protein kinases in eukaryotic cells? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asparagine

 

Explanation:

 

Protein kinases in eukaryotic cells catalyze the phosphorylation of specific amino acid residues by transferring the terminal phosphoryl group of ATP to their hydroxyl groups. Protein kinases phosphorylate commonly three types of amino acid residues: serine, threonine, and tyrosine, forming O-phosphoseryl, O-phosphothreonyl, or O-phosphotyrosyl residues, respectively. Asparagine lacks the hydroxyl group  for this phosphoryl transfer reaction, making it unsuitable as a substrate for protein kinases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Threonine: This is incorrect because threonine is one of the three amino acids that can be phosphorylated by protein kinases. Its hydroxyl group serves as the site for attachment of the phosphoryl group.

 

Option B. Tyrosine: This is incorrect because tyrosine is specifically one of the three amino acids that can be phosphorylated by protein kinases through its hydroxyl group.

 

Option C. Serine: This is incorrect because serine is one of the primary targets for protein kinases. Its hydroxyl group readily accepts the phosphoryl group during the phosphorylation reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Protein kinases are highly specific enzymes that catalyze the transfer of phosphoryl groups to the hydroxyl groups of serine, threonine, or tyrosine residues in proteins, not to amino acids lacking hydroxyl groups such as asparagine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Milk

 

Explanation

 

Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.

 

Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).

 

Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:

 

  1. Delays emptying of stomach
  2. Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  3. Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances

 

Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.

 

Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulose: A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.

 

Option B. Inulin: A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.

 

Option C. Pectin: Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Measles vaccine and Vitamin A supplementation

questions.text: An unvaccinated 4-year-old child presents with rashes, fever, and Bitot spot. This can be managed appropriately by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isolation and Vitamin A supplementation

 

Explanation: 


When a child presents with measles (characterized by rashes, fever, and Bitot spots), the management involves two critical components:

 

  1. Isolation: Measles is highly contagious, so the child must be isolated to prevent spread to other individuals, especially those who are unvaccinated or immunocompromised.
  2. Vitamin A Supplementation: Vitamin A is crucial in managing measles because:
    • It reduces the severity of the disease
    • Decreases complications
    • Helps reduce mortality, especially in children with vitamin A deficiency
    • Supports immune system function during the infection

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Supportive care only: Incorrect. While supportive care is important, it is insufficient. Vitamin A supplementation is a critical intervention in measles management.

 

Option C. Measles vaccine and Vitamin A supplementation: Incorrect. Once a child has active measles, vaccination is no longer beneficial. The vaccine is preventive, not a treatment for ongoing infection.

 

Option D. Measles vaccine only: Incorrect. A child with active measles cannot be vaccinated during the acute phase of the illness. Vaccination is ineffective and potentially harmful at this stage.

 

Educational Objective: 


In active measles infection, isolation and Vitamin A supplementation are the key management strategies, with Vitamin A playing a crucial role in reducing disease severity and complications.

questions.text: The defined population norm for Urban-Primary health centre in our country is one such centre per: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 per 50,000

 

In India, the population norm for establishing a UPHC is one center per 50,000 population. These centers are intended to provide primary healthcare services in urban areas, addressing the healthcare needs of urban populations efficiently.

 

The UPHCs are equipped to deliver a range of health services, including preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative care.

 

In UPHC, one Urban Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) per 10,000 population, and one Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) per 1,000 to 2,500 population.

 

Remember –

 

Population norm for rural PHC

 

  • 1 per 30,000 populations in plain area
  • 1 per 20,000 populations in tribal and hilly areas

 

Educational Objective:

 

The population norm for establishing an Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) in India is one center per 50,000 populations.

choices.text: 90% is associated with ANCA positivity
30% is associated with Hepatitis B

questions.text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 30% association with Hepatitis B

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis predominantly affecting medium-sized arteries, often associated with Hepatitis B in about 30% of cases. The association with Hepatitis B is significant because the virus can trigger immune complex deposition, contributing to vascular inflammation and damage characteristic of PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing inflammation of large vessels: This is incorrect because PAN specifically affects medium-sized, not large vessels. Large vessel vasculitis includes conditions like Giant Cell Arteritis and Takayasu Arteritis.

 

Option B. Patient has hypogammaglobulinemia: This is incorrect; PAN is often associated with hypergammaglobulinemia due to chronic immune activation, not hypogammaglobulinemia.

 

Option C. 90% is associated with ANCA positivity: This statement is also incorrect. Polyarteritis nodosa is typically ANCA-negative; the presence of ANCA is more characteristic of other forms of vasculitis such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) and Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lachman’s test

 

The image shows the examiner performing a test where the knee is placed in 20 to 30 degrees of flexion and the tibia is pulled anteriorly. This describes the Lachman’s test, which is used to assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

 

  • The Lachman’s test is preferred over the anterior drawer test for diagnosing ACL injuries because it can be performed with the knee in slight flexion, which isolates the ACL and reduces the influence of other structures. A positive Lachman’s test, indicated by increased anterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur, suggests an ACL tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior drawer test: The anterior drawer test is also used to assess ACL injuries but differs from the Lachman’s test in that the knee is flexed at 90 degrees. In the anterior drawer test, the examiner pulls the tibia forward while stabilizing the leg, but this test can be less sensitive than the Lachman’s test in acute injuries.

 

Option C. McMurray’s test: McMurray’s test is used to evaluate meniscal injuries, not ligamentous injuries. It involves flexing the knee and applying rotational forces to check for a meniscal tear. It is done with the knee in 90 degrees of flexion and involves listening for clicking or popping sounds in the meniscus.

 

Option D. Posterior drawer test: The posterior drawer test is used to assess the integrity of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). It is performed with the knee at 90 degrees of flexion, and the examiner pushes the tibia backward. This is not the test being performed in the image, as the tibia is being pulled anteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lachman’s test is the most reliable physical exam maneuver for diagnosing ACL tears, performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion.

questions.text: Which term is used to describe the first case of a disease that comes to the attention of an investigator? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) Index case

 

The index case is defined as the first case of a disease that comes to the attention of the investigator. This is an important epidemiological concept because the index case may not necessarily be the first case that occurred in the population. The index case is the one that triggers the investigation, leading to the identification of other cases in an outbreak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient Zero: A synonym for Index case but is a less precise term: it may be used to describe either the first case of the disease, the first case on record, or the first case within a specific group

 

Option C. Primary case - The primary case refers to the first case of a communicable disease introduced into the population unit being studied. The primary case represents the actual first occurrence in the outbreak, not the first one detected by health officials.

 

Option D. Secondary case - Secondary cases are those that develop from contact with the primary case. These represent subsequent transmission in the outbreak chain, not the first identified case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In epidemiological investigations, the index case (first identified) is distinguished from the primary case (first occurrence), which is crucial for accurate outbreak investigation and understanding transmission dynamics.

questions.text: Which fontanelle is the last to close during normal skull development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior

 

The anterior fontanelle (Bregma) is the largest and most prominent fontanelle on a baby's skull.

 

The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close. It closes at around 18-24 months of age.

 

These openings in the skull allow for flexibility during childbirth and rapid brain growth during infancy. Fontanelles gradually close as the bones of the skull grow and fuse.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Fontanelle (Lambda):

 

  • The posterior fontanelle is located at the junction of the occipital and parietal bones of the skull. Unlike the anterior fontanelle, the posterior fontanelle is smaller and less noticeable.
  • The posterior fontanelle usually closes within the first few months of life.

 

Option C. Occipital Fontanelle (Sphenoidal):

 

  • The term "occipital fontanelle" is less commonly used, and it may refer to a small soft spot located at the back of the head, near the occipital bone. This area is generally less significant than the anterior and posterior fontanelles and closes early in infancy.

 

Option D. Mastoid Fontanelle:

 

  • The term "mastoid fontanelle" is not commonly used in the context of fontanelles on a baby's skull.
  • The mastoid region of the skull is a bony area located behind the ear, and it does not typically have a soft spot or fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

  • MRI can cause movements of an intraocular foreign body (OFB) if it is magnetic and is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies.
  • The most common foreign bodies to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel.
  • Foreign bodies entering the eye may cause damage by mechanical effects, introduction of infection, or reacting with the intraocular tissues.
  • Localization of intraocular foreign body can be done through:
    1. Radiographic: Limbal ring method, which is the simplest but sparingly employed technique.
    2. Ultrasonographic: Can tell the position of even non-radio-opaque foreign bodies.
    3. CT scan: Presently the best method of intraocular foreign body localization, providing cross-sectional images with superior sensitivity and specificity than plain radiography and ultrasonography.

 

  • A foreign body should always be removed unless it is inert and probably sterile, little damage has been done to vision, or the process of removal will destroy sight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT: CT scan is highly effective for detecting and localizing metallic foreign bodies. It provides detailed cross-sectional images without the risks associated with MRI.

 

Option C. X-ray: X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies and is a safe initial imaging modality. However, it is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option D. B mode scan: B mode ultrasound can help localize non-radio-opaque foreign bodies and assess intraocular damage. It is safe and commonly used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

questions.text: Theophylline was prescribed to a male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The next day, he noticed that his urine output had increased. Which of the following receptors is responsible for the drug's action? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine A1

 

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that primarily acts as a nonselective adenosine receptor antagonist. By antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, theophylline can lead to diuresis or increased urine output. Adenosine normally promotes water reabsorption in the renal tubules, and its blockade by theophylline results in increased urine production. This mechanism is separate from its therapeutic action in COPD, which involves bronchodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interleukin-10: Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine. It is not a direct target of theophylline. IL-10 plays a role in regulating immune responses, but it is not involved in the diuretic effect or the primary action of theophylline in COPD treatment.

 

Option B. Histone Deacetylase: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) is an enzyme involved in chromatin remodelling and gene expression regulation. While theophylline has been suggested to have some modulatory effects on HDAC, especially in the context of COPD and asthma, it is not the mechanism responsible for the increased urine output observed in the patient.

 

Option D. Beta 2 Adrenergic Receptors: While theophylline has mild bronchodilatory effects thought to be mediated through inhibition of phosphodiesterase (increasing cAMP levels in smooth muscle), leading to relaxation of bronchial smooth muscles, beta 2 adrenergic receptors are more specifically targeted by drugs like salbutamol. Theophylline's diuretic effect is not mediated through beta 2 adrenergic receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Theophylline increases urine output by antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, leading to decreased water reabsorption in the renal tubules and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: Rokitansky protuberance is most commonly associated with which of the following tumors? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Teratoma

 

Explanation: 

 

Rokitansky protuberance is a characteristic feature of mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) of the ovary. It refers to a solid, nodular projection from the wall of the cyst that often contains teeth and/or hair. The mature teratomas typically contain a mixture of tissues including skin, hair, cartilage, and sebaceous glands. They are described as having a ball of hair and a nodular projection from which teeth may protrude, which precisely describes the Rokitansky protuberance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sex cord-stromal tumors - These tumors arise from the specialized gonadal stroma and include granulosa-theca cell tumors, Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, and fibroma-thecomas. They don't form cystic structures with Rokitansky protuberances but instead have their own distinctive morphologic patterns, often related to their hormone-producing capabilities.

 

Option C. Dysgerminoma - This is the ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma and is described as the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. Dysgerminomas are typically solid rather than cystic tumors. They don't form Rokitansky protuberances but instead show characteristic histologic features with polyhedral cells, distinct cell membranes, and watery cytoplasm.

 

Option D. Yolk sac tumor - Also called endodermal sinus tumor, this is described as the second most common malignant germ cell tumor in the ovary and the most common malignant ovarian tumor in girls under 4 years of age. Histologically, it's characterized by Schiller-Duval bodies/glomeruloid bodies, not Rokitansky protuberances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rokitansky protuberance is a pathognomonic feature of mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) of the ovary, representing a solid nodular area within the cyst that typically contains differentiated tissues such as teeth, bone, cartilage, and hair.

choices.text: Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness
Activates locus coeruleus and cause wakefulness
No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep
Activates histamine release and prevents sleep

questions.text: A man habitually consumes coffee before bedtime and claims difficulty in sleep during night. What is the role of caffeine in wakefulness? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness

 

Caffeine is a stimulant that is commonly consumed to reduce fatigue and increase alertness. Its primary mechanism of action in promoting wakefulness is through blocking the action of adenosine, a neurotransmitter in the brain that promotes sleep and relaxation by binding to adenosine receptors. Normally, when adenosine binds to its receptors, it leads to drowsiness and a decrease in nerve cell activity. Caffeine, due to its structural similarity to adenosine, competes for these receptors but does not activate them. Instead, it blocks the action of adenosine, preventing the onset of sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness: The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in physiological responses to stress and panic, and it is active during REM sleep to help regulate wakefulness. However, caffeine does not directly activate the locus coeruleus to cause wakefulness; instead, its wakefulness-promoting effect is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade.

 

Option C. No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep: This statement is incorrect because caffeine does play a significant role in maintaining wakefulness even if consumed an hour before sleep. Caffeine has a half-life of about 5-6 hours, meaning it remains active in the system for several hours after consumption, potentially leading to difficulty falling asleep.

 

Option D. Activates histamine release and prevents sleep: Histamine is a neurotransmitter involved in wakefulness, but caffeine does not exert its wakefulness-promoting effects through histamine release. The primary mechanism is through blocking adenosine receptors, not activating histamine release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily by blocking adenosine receptors in the brain, thereby preventing the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine.

questions.text: The most common Mullerian anomaly is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Septate Uterus

 

Septate uterus is the most common mullerian anomaly, representing approximately 35% of all Müllerian anomalies. This condition occurs when the two Müllerian ducts are fused together but there is persistence of the septum between them, which can be either partial (subseptate) or complete. It is typically associated with poor reproductive outcomes including infertility, recurrent abortions, and mid-trimester pregnancy losses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine Agenesis: Uterine agenesis (MRKH syndrome) is characterized by absent uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes and partial vagina. While significant, it is not the most common Müllerian anomaly.

 

Option B. Unicornuate Uterus: Unicornuate uterus represents only about 10% of Müllerian anomalies. It results from failure of development of one Müllerian duct, often presenting with a rudimentary horn that may cause complications like ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option C. Bicornuate Uterus: Bicornuate uterus accounts for approximately 26% of Müllerian anomalies. It involves varying degrees of fusion of the muscle walls of the two ducts, but is still not as common as the septate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septate uterus is the most common Müllerian anomaly and is associated with significant reproductive complications, with hysteroscopic septoplasty being the treatment of choice for patients with recurrent pregnancy losses.

questions.text: In a solid organ transplantation, which organ is associated with a higher incidence of rejection? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens and their role in gas exchange, which increases the risk of immune-mediated injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestine: Intestinal transplantation also carries a high risk of rejection, but it is less common than lung rejection and is often associated with complications such as graft-versus-host disease.

 

Option C. Kidney: Kidney transplantation has a relatively lower incidence of rejection compared to lung and intestinal transplants due to the kidney's immunologically privileged status and the availability of effective immunosuppressive medications.

 

Option D. Heart: While heart transplantation can also lead to rejection, it generally has a lower incidence compared to lung transplantation, possibly due to differences in the immune response and the heart's unique anatomical and physiological characteristics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens, emphasizing the need for vigilant monitoring and immunosuppressive therapy in lung transplant recipients.

choices.text: Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing
Telomerase is found in somatic cells

questions.text: True about telomeres and telomerase is:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing

 

This statement is correct. Telomeres naturally shorten with each cell division, and this gradual shortening is associated with the aging process. It's a result of the end replication problem, where the DNA replication machinery cannot fully replicate the ends of linear chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomere length with ageing: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres, the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, tend to shorten with each cell division and are associated with aging. Over time, this can contribute to cellular senescence and aging.

 

Option C. Telomeres have coding sequences: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres do not contain coding sequences for proteins. Instead, they consist of repetitive DNA sequences that provide a buffer zone to protect the essential genetic information during cell division.

 

Option D. Telomerase is found in somatic cells: This statement is generally incorrect. Telomerase, the enzyme that can counteract telomere shortening by adding repetitive DNA sequences, is typically more active in germ cells and certain stem cells. In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is low, contributing to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomeres are end of chromosomes and do not contain any coding sequences. Instead it has TTAGGG sequence repeated ‘n’ no. of times.

 

Telomerase is enzyme present only in the germ/stem cells and is responsible for maintaining the length of telomeres due to its RNA dependent DNA polymerase activity.

 

In Somatic cells, absence of telomerase enzyme (option d is false) results in telomere shortening as the cells ages.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 355, 716
